thread.title: Smartphone app helps identify more than 50 species of dragonfly
thread.title_full: Smartphone app helps identify more than 50 species of dragonfly

author: Felicity James
title: Smartphone app helps identify more than 50 species of dragonfly
text:
A new smartphone app for identifying dragonflies in Australia's tropical regions promises to share and expand research on the insect. Some dragonflies found in the app: Aurora bluetail (damselfly) Found: Australiawide Australasian slimwing (dragonfly) Found: Northern NT, costal and northern Queensland Australian tiger ( dragonfly). Found: northern Australia Blue percher ( dragonfly) . Found: northern Australia, southeast Asia Iridescent flutterer (dragonfly) Found: northern Australia Tiny longlegs (damselfly) . Found: northern NT, Cape York, New Guinea Palemouth (dragonfly). Found: northern Australia, New Guinea 
Part of Northern Territory folklore, flocks of dragonflies are viewed as a sign the dry season is about to begin. 
Dragonfly expert Professor Jenny Davis from Charles Darwin University created the app to remove some of the mystery surrounding the insect after studying it in Kakadu National Park. 
"The tropics are where dragonflies have diversified," she said. 
"There's something like 300 species and 100 of those occur here in the north, so we have a third of Australia's fauna." 
The species seen in the Northern Territory at the end of the wet season live in temporary water bodies, which become dry, Professor Davis said. Photo: A rhyothemis graphiptera, or Graphic flutterer/banded flutterer, dragonfly grabs hold of a particularly nice piece of wood in the NT (ABC Open: Matt B) 
"Those big flocks are flying around looking for mates," she said. 
"Once they mate, they're then going to look for somewhere to lay their eggs and the eggs will sit there until the next wet season." Audio: Listen to Felicity James' full story here (PM) 
More than 50 species of dragonfly have been included in the Identifly app, which Professor Davis said would be useful for dragonfly-watchers beyond the Northern Territory. 
According to Professor Davis, the dragonflies included in the app could be spotted from Cape York to the Kimberley and in neighbouring countries such as Indonesia and Timor-Leste. 
Peter Dostine, an ecologist working in the Northern Territory's Environment Department, said most of the research into the region's dragonflies was done in the 1980s, and that more information about dragonfly distribution would be useful. 
"They're an important ecological group, they're predators both as larvae and as adults," he said. 
"As adults they eat large numbers of small flying insects, including mosquitos." 
Research for the project began 20 years ago in Kakadu National Park, according to Professor Davis, after a traditional owner from the region said he wanted more information about dragonflies to share with tourists. 
"I talked to one of the traditional owners, who sadly has since passed away, and asked him if there was anything to do with the wetlands and particularly the bugs, the freshwater insects of the wetlands, that he would like done," Professor Davis said. 
It wasn't until Professor Davis had a visit from her son, who is now an app developer, that her dragonfly guide was given new life. 
"He and his partner were visiting and a dragonfly flew past and I said 'I can tell you the name of that and I've actually got a guide to it all, do you remember going out and looking at dragonflies?'" 
"He said 'Mum, I could turn that into an app for you'." 
Filling knowledge gaps about distribution of the dragonfly would be the project's next step, according to Professor Davis. 
Professor Davis said the app would be updated so people can enter the location they spot a particular species. 
"We really feel this is going to open up this area of environmental knowledge in a way that hasn't been possible previously."
